data.sampled:
It's generally not a good practice to "fully" explaining your reasoning or solutions to logic puzzles to the user/reader. It could potentially spoil their enjoyment of the puzzle, or worse, prevent them from learning from the experience by working through it themselves (if it's someone learning how to do logic puzzles).

The Half-Explain technique can be helpful. Tell them some of the reasoning, or enough to put them on the right track, but leave the final deduction and/or follow-up steps for them to figure out for themselves. This can lead to a better, more rewarding learning experience, especially when the solver is learning a new concept.

Here are some examples of Half-Explain techniques that work well for logic puzzles:
-
Struggling learners can have an even harder time gaining meaning from complete solutions. If they don't understand one step in your explanation, the whole thing will just be gibberish and discouraging to them. Half-Explains allow them to be successful by allowing them to engage with the material basically up to their current ability (and a little bit beyond so that they're learning something new).

Any time you're helping with a task that could be a learning opportunity, consider whether it's appropriate to fully explain, or if Half-Explaining might be better.
